history.content: In an undirected graph, the degree of a vertex is the number of incident edges In a directed graph we talk of the in-degree & the out-degree, being respectively the number of edges entering that vertex, & the number of edges leaving that vertex. You may occasionally see talk of simply 'the degree' of vertices in directed graphs; normally that would be the sum of the in-degree plus the out-degree NB self-loops are treated identically, so a self-loop in an undirected graph adds 2 to the degree, a self-loop in a directed graph adds 1 to the in-degree & 1 to the out-degree wikipedia Loop Degree

In an undirected graph, the degree of a vertex is the number of incident edges In a directed graph we talk of the in-degree & the out-degree, being respectively the number of edges entering that vertex, & the number of edges leaving that vertex. You may occasionally see talk of simply 'the degree' of vertices in directed graphs; normally that would be the sum of the in-degree plus the out-degree NB self-loops are treated identically, so a self-loop in an undirected graph adds 2 to the degree, a self-loop in a directed graph adds 1 to the in-degree & 1 to the out-degree wikipedia Loop

In an undirected graph, the degree of a vertex is the number of incident edges

In a directed graph we talk of the in-degree & the out-degree, being respectively the number of edges entering that vertex, & the number of edges leaving that vertex. You may occasionally see talk of simply 'the degree' of vertices in directed graphs; normally that would be the sum of the in-degree plus the out-degree

In an undirected graph, the degree of a vertex is the number of incident edges

In a directed graph we talk of the out-degree & the in-degree, being respectively the number of edges entering that vertex, & the number of edges leaving that vertex. You may occasionally see talk of simply 'the degree' of vertices in directed graphs; normally that would be the sum of the in-degree plus the out-degree
The way I understand it is the degree of a vertex corresponds to the number of inbound edges. A source vertex is degree 0.

DPV 3.6. 3.9 , 3.26, 3.27  has this concept of vertices having degree. 

3.6 explains degree is nothing but number of neighbors/edges. 

Is that the general meaning of degree in graphs ?
history.subject: DPV 3.6 and Degree
